subject: Better Late Than Not Submitting Papers
header: This week, lots of small things. And a rather urgent call for papers for FOSDEM. How urgent? The event is next week. 'Nuff said?

entries.text: PAUSE has a new home. Everything went smoothly, biggest change: FTP access to PAUSE has gone bye-bye (uploads are done via HTTP/HTTPS).
entries.title: pause.perl.org moved

entries.text: FOSDEM. It's in Brussels. It's February 2nd and 3rd. And they need Perl speakers. Will you answer the call?
entries.title: Perl@FOSDEM2013: A very late Call for Papers

entries.text: ... and 5.18.0 is really not very far either. (at last news, it should be landing in May)
entries.title: Perl 5.17.8 is now available

entries.text: Registrations and talk submissions are now open. Go.
entries.title: YAPC::NA 2013 in Texas, June 3-5.

entries.text: Want to find files on your system? Lots of files? Ricardo Signes offers a review of the hunter-killer modules out there, and how do they perform in function of the size of the haystack they have to wade through.
entries.title: the speed of Perl file finders

entries.text: So, there's that concept that Perl is kinda undead flying around.  And, as gothic literature taught us, the Coded Undead (also known as Nosferaturings) need a constant input of young blood if they don't want to crumble into dusty irrelevance. In a somewhat related spirit, VM Brasseur discusses how we could, and should, improve our outreach to new programmers to keep our continued existence on the road to sparkliness.
entries.title: Improving Perl's New Programmer Outreach

entries.text: Cosimo Streppone shows us his Perl port of statsd, and how it can holds its ground against the original nodejs implementation.
entries.title: Net::Statsd::Server, a Perl port of Flickr/Etsy's statsd

entries.text: By "guest-editing the Perl Weekly", Gabor meant "write a new database backend for it". And a web front-end. With HTML 5 shinies, and perhaps use a pet templating system while we are at it? ... Right?
entries.title: Newsmill (aka an excuse to play with shinies)

entries.text: Domm's blog engine, Blio, has been updated. Amongst the new features: automatic publishing via git hooks.
entries.title: Blio updates

entries.text: A new install tool from tokuhirom, inspired by Ruby's rbenv.
entries.title: plenv - brand new perl5 installation management tool

entries.text: You want to carve into your name into the very code of Perl, but fear your hack-fu is not strong enough?  Balderdash! Here's a meta-ticket corralling a bunch of smaller tasks that don't require the mastery of eldritch technologies. Verily, only a wee bit of elbow grease stands before you and history, so hurry up!
entries.title: Core Perl tickets requiring no C, perlguts, or OS expertise

entries.text: Forewarned is forearmed. Some core modules have received the black patch and shall disappear from the Perl core library before 5.20 is out.  Do you know which ones?
entries.title: Modules to be removed before 5.20.0

entries.text: Harvesting information off web pages. We all do it. Sometimes wholesale, sometimes cherry-picking information with regular expressions, sometimes being fancier with XPath. And how about using CSS selectors? Ulrich Habel shows us how.
entries.title: Scraping the web (Web::Scraper) and CSS

entries.text: chromatic reminds us why most grown men cry when Unicode enter the picture (which, nowadays, is pretty much constantly).
entries.title: Why Unicode Normalization Matters

entries.text: Dist::Zilla is awesome, but a little bit on the slow side. Olivier Mengué asks us to help to optimize its plugins for speed, and provides a few tricks and tools to profile the beast.
entries.title: Profiling Dist::Zilla

entries.text: The obvious Guitar Hero variation for hackers, courtesy of Macieja Ciemborowicza.
entries.title: Terminal Hero

entries.text: Sometimes we come up with useful stuff. Sometimes, it's not that useful, but it still pretty darn cool. This command-line commit sparkline generator by Eric squarely falls under the latter category.
entries.title: git-spark plots your commit history

entries.text: The rise of the machines is upon us. And it's adorable. A new major version of Parrot, codenamed for the lovable cousin of the T-800, is out. Amongst other things, it now comes with yummy thread support.
entries.title: Parrot 5.0.0 "Johnny Five Alive" Released!
